_data.text:
Empower your NuxtJS application with `@nuxtjs/content` module: write in a `content/` directory and fetch your Markdown, JSON, YAML and CSV files through a MongoDB like API, acting as a **Git-based Headless CMS**.

## Writing content

Learn how to write your `content/`, supporting Markdown, YAML, CSV and JSON: https://content.nuxtjs.org/writing.

## Fetching content

Learn how to fetch your content with `$content`: https://content.nuxtjs.org/fetching.

## Displaying content

Learn how to display your Markdown content with the `<nuxt-content>` component directly in your template: https://content.nuxtjs.org/displaying.

Hello everybody! I'm a gameplay engineer at the studio, although I have a habit of getting my fingers into as many pies as is physically possible.
Also, I am a strong advocate for pies. Especially on Pi Day.
I am literally struggling to get work done because of this channel

Actual science incoming!
Einar is about 2.75 m tall, plus or minus the straw hat. When T-posed his wingspan is about 2.9 m, but his hands mostly hang down, so that does not affect potatoes. 
If he is standing still, he would fit into a 1x1x2.75 m silo. In the terribly confusing metric system that is exactly 2.75 cubic meters, or in the superior Imperial system we can instantly see that 3.2 x 3.2 x 9 ft = ~97 cubic feet.
Depending on size and lumpiness potatoes can range from about 42 to about 48 lbs per cubic foot. Since potatoes are not perfect cubes, some of the volume they fill is air, so I guess smaller more evenly-shaped potatoes weigh more than larger lumpier ones. If we assume a nice harvest of nice medium sized potatoes shaped closer to bricks than footballs, we can settle on 46 lbs / ft3.
This gives us 4,462lbs of potatoes to fill the same silo. We just gotta remember to crane Einar out first.
We desperately really need a #potato-chat channel now

messages.content: Will this game  have some sort of economy ?
Some sort, for sure!

Conversation in the other channel gave me a thought. As a gaming dad with an 8 year old that wants to play things like this, I've had to explore how to disable chat and enforce stricter moderation than when I'm playing. Of course, you can always disable chat, etc. but I'd love to see a parental control toggle feature that locks down aspects of a game with one click to save me the headache of turning it all on/off depending on if I'm at the keyboard or she is.

Really can't promise anything in the short term because it's a lot of work to build out complex controls, but we are aiming to be able to have a flexible system that can allow players to account for different social situations.

Did you guys take any inspiration from My Time In Portia? I felt like they did a lot of things right (automation of gathering, combat that's not super difficult but rewarding if you do it, general progression feeling, etc) Will there be any automation of gathering at a later point in the game?

Overwhelming majority of us are at S6 because we love these exact games and we played them all. Inspiration is probably the wrong word, since game developers often tend to see all games at least somewhat critically. Influenced, maybe - as in, we tend to have long discussions about how different games approach the same feature, and what we feel works and what we feel does not. Portia certainly has a lot of great ideas, but there is no single title where we would go "let's do our X exactly like game ABC"

What about gear/equipment and such? Is it going to be pretty streamlined and simple?

Yes. You have your cosmetic outfits, of which we already have a dazzling variety. You also have your tools, like pickaxe, fishing rod, butterfly net. These have quality tiers, but you only have one at a time, e.g. a higher-quality axe replaces the lower-tier one, you're not juggling both. There's a huge variety of harvestable and gatherable and craftable items that you can have in your inventory. Tools specifically, we do want it to be as easy and seamless as possible so you're not constantly swapping items and switching to inventory management after every activity.

message.content: Hey everyone! I'm Mr.BroBacon, senior tech artist working with the environment team to make the world feel alive! Super excited for people to learn more about Palia!

messages.content: Hey little question, because i didn't really catch it, will there be a combat system in the Game like other mmos or Stardew Valley or are there no plans for that? Best regards Tobi
There are plans for a combat system but it's not the main focus at the moment. ‚öîÔ∏è
i heard about a co-op mechanic in the game can i get a explanation on how exactly this co-op function will work if there is one?
There are technically going to be multiple co-op mechanics in the game - we want as many mechanics as possible to have co-op opportunities.
Will there be cross platform support, something like a mobile or console client so I can fish while at work? üòÜ  Similar functionality to say Runescape mobile for example
We are starting on PC only but long term do want to grow into a cross platform game.

On a related note to the server/sharding question, how will housing and building plots be regulated? Will there be a form of competition for them? Will players be able to build everywhere? How would you prevent players from littering the game world with unused buildings, or making rudimentary 'not really safe for work' pixel art with them (or make areas look like a minecraft server where the main building tools were wood, obsidian and dynamite)? Are you considering splitting the community by instancing building areas? If so, how would you guarantee a community feeling when the community would be split up? Whatever happens i hope that last thing won't happen (see wow for why).

Currently our housing is instanced off in private spaces - there will be ways for players to show off their plots but it will not be so free [edit - as running by someone's home]. As such, there is no shortage of real estate for players to have access to housing.

On a related note to the server/sharding question, how will housing and building plots be regulated? Will there be a form of competition for them? Will players be able to build everywhere? How would you prevent players from littering the game world with unused buildings, or making rudimentary 'not really safe for work' pixel art with them (or make areas look like a minecraft server where the main building tools were wood, obsidian and dynamite)? Are you considering splitting the community by instancing building areas? If so, how would you guarantee a community feeling when the community would be split up? Whatever happens i hope that last thing won't happen (see wow for why).

<@!849849433402245170> Bit of a weird question, but what's the best way you could describe your job? I hear a new description from every tech artist and figured might as well ask one of the best if he's free üëÄ

Yeah, the thing with TechArt is that it's a very wide net that encompasses a lot of different specializations. Some tech artists are more shader specialists, or tools and pipeline, or tech systems, etc. While a tech artist generally specializes in one category we end up working on all these different aspects of the game. My main responsibilities are making the systems that allow the world to feel alive, that entails working on the shaders but also the script and code needed to control and support the feature I'm working on. I'm also responsible for the performances of the environment, I need to make sure that while it looks good and feels alive it needs to be able to run on our defined platforms. I hope that answers your question!

Can't give a concrete answer and I don't want to speak *on behalf* of our designers. But I can say that I have the utmost confidence in the people directly involved in making decisions about social interactions between players, with consideration for griefing and harassment.

messages.content: Sure, that sounds like a sensible starting point for such a system, frankly. "Affordable" is a very context sensitive qualifier though. It all comes down to priorities, too. It's not merely "do we make a music playing feature" or not, it's choosing to do it versus something else, and the many many many knock on effects. Maybe a naive implementation ends up annihilating server performance? What if all the network traffic for that ends up doubling server costs in practice? What about people intentionally being a noise nuisance to others? This just a tiny slice of the amount that has to go into making a thoughtful, quality, cozy welcoming world for everyone.

Question: Many of your players will be coming from World of Warcraft, likely following some of the devs. I'm wondering how Singularity 6 will be handling the comparisons of Palia to WOW, Stardew, and others. And how will Singularity 6 react to comparisons between them as a company and the companies that own the aforementioned MMOs?

Well, technically, we're already handling lots of comparisons to those games here already.  We take inspiration from a lot of the mentioned games, but at the end of the day we're hoping to forge our own path. Many games are lackluster because they try too hard to be exactly like something else already on the market. That said, we're going to borrow a lot of valuable components from those games, but we will not hold ourselves accountable to mimicking them. üôÇ

message.content: Say you want a fish that's only caught in the morning.  If you start fishing when "morning" hits you will have 15 minutes (give or take!) of straight fishing you can do and have a chance to catch what you want.
And if you are not successful then morning will come around again in about 45 minutes of real time.

saw some discussion further up about the Pre-Alpha/Alpha, which makes me a little curious. Devs, what do you internally consider the distinction between Pre-Alpha and Alpha to be? I feel like often these state of the game terminologies mean different things for different development studios.

That, no doubt, you can get as many answers as there are people probably. The issue has more to do with words as *described* versus words as *prescribed*. Personally, all these terms are vague and nebulous to me, except for in relation to each other. On a scale of "this is all prototype" to "this is representative of the quality and polish where people feel comfortable not having to qualify everything as still-in-development", it's easy enough to say alpha - beta - release. But a lot of that is less meaningful in the world of online games that continue to be developed for years, even a decade or more.

<@!733088119280369757> since you worked on character customization, with colors, is it a color wheel or more of a set palette to choose from?

Likely to evolve over time. At the moment, some things like hair color are a palette, and other items have authored color variants. That could change tomorrow, that could change a year from now. There are interesting design concerns about absolute freedom to pick any colors whatsoever versus making it hard for people to feel like they're picking an aesthetically pleasing color palette versus candidates for the Monster Factory YouTube channel (is that a good thing? Is that a bad thing? ü§∑).

Speaking of small, doesnt a party size of 4 alienate the sense of "massive" from an mmo? Party size is not a set in stone thing. I realize a team member may have given an explicit number based on their understanding at the time, but that kind of info is at best giving a snapshot of the current state of things that absolutely may (or may not) change. I can't elaborate any more than that confidently.

I'm not sure if questions for the devs posted here will just get lost, but here goes... I'm a game developer and game academic (Michigan State University). Mostly my partner and I have been working on "Friendship Games" and that was one of the things that made Palia jump out at us. We have been doing research around relationships through games and in particular how some games do it better / worse. We are really interested in folks who are being intentional in making games that foster new friendships/connections (Sky for mobile is an interesting recent example). But, we are curious if the devs would / could talk about what mechanics, tools or systems they see as being integral to Palia for developing (good/better) community and relationships? We are working on a paper now that discusses League of Legends and WoW (WoW over time really...) and other games in relation to these topics and would love to talk about Palia and what y'all doing different. Hope it is ok to <@!786370144120209478> with this one. Apologies if not. üôÇ
Not sure how soon we're gonna be able to talk about particulars, but that sounds like a super cool area of study! Anything published yet that we should take a look at? üôÇ

messages.content: Why did you choose the name "Palia" for the game?

While I can't say exactly why we settled on "Palia" over others (I wasn't part of that explicit process), I can say that finding a name for a game is really hard!  From what I understand we had a long list of names, some lawyers had to check a buuunch of things to make sure there were no IP or copyright issues and just a few made it out of that process. You can't just pick the best name and go with it, unfortunately.

Ok I just thought of something that might and might not be a valid question, but Im gonna ask anyway üòÖ 
For the players that get into the pre-Alpha - do they get to only play the game as casual players? Or would they be allowed access to, let¬¥s say more materials, so that they can advance through the content faster? It was said that there is quite a big chunk of the game for the testers to play in, but will there be enough time to really explore that chunk? Some players might not have as much time on their hands and wouldn¬¥t be able to "farm" all the resources needed. Please don¬¥t take this as If Im spoiled and want benefits or anything üòÖ At this point we don¬¥t even know who gets to play the pre-Alpha. I thought of this simply because Im one of the players that would rather build and explore, rather than farm resources and Im not sure If there will be enough time for people like me to enjoy building and other resource-expensive things.
We want to understand how players progress through the current content, so accelerating that process would be a bad move for our learning.

Everyone is bringing up great points. There are lots of advantages and disadvantages of each model. **But there is no best.** Only tradeoffs. Or best for certain people. messages.content: No, it's really about the timing. People are very, very sensitive to the timing of musical notes. If your ping is 80 ms and someone else's ping is 80 ms, it could be 160 ms for the note you hit to *start* playing. So if you're both trying to time everything together, there's actual a 160+ ms delay *both ways*.

referenced_message.content: Wouldn¬¥t help If the music could be heard only by a smaller number of players? Like having It have radius or only the party members could hear It and so on?

messages.content: Sea of Thieves have a System for Music which is great. Sure there are 'pre scripted' Events. But the Server-Client communication is well so that when people join they just add another line of music to the already played Track. So its not 'that hard'. Only if you would make it completly played by the players itself.

messages.content:
I also dont think this is economical interesting.

But lets get into the theory:
You have 10 Instruments. and 10 Songs in the Game you can buy/learn.  You need a 'song line' for the instrument to record and if another player in a radius of x-metres joins the 'Music-Play' and he has the track learned he can join the Musical-Group.

Just by this you have 100 different SKills you could learn.

Its a concept which is also affordable to develop in a game and not too hard. Also giving Content for the players

referenced_message.content: Right. It's not impossble or unfeasible. But it is not as simple as letting people press a key to make a sound. No one would be happy with that version of it.

messages.content: Sure, that sounds like a sensible starting point for such a system, frankly. "Affordable" is a very context sensitive qualifier though. It all comes down to priorities, too. It's not merely "do we make a music playing feature" or not, it's choosing to do it versus something else, and the many many many knock on effects. Maybe a naive implementation ends up annihilating server performance? What if all the network traffic for that ends up doubling server costs in practice? What about people intentionally being a noise nuisance to others? This just a tiny slice of the amount that has to go into making a thoughtful, quality, cozy welcoming world for everyone.
